properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 10 to 25 cm of snow is expected this weekend. Hazards: 10 to 25 cm of snow Poor road conditions due to accumulating snow Timing: Snow will begin Saturday morning and last into Sunday. The heaviest snow is expected Saturday afternoon through Sunday morning. Discussion: This snow is a result of an approaching Texas low that will spread precipitation across a large portion of southern Ontario and parts of northeastern Ontario beginning Friday overnight. Snowfall warnings will be considered as the event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-12T01:45:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-11T09:46:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1668933658.2020
Area: West Nipissing - French River, North Bay - Powassan - Mattawa, Espanola - Killarney, Manitoulin Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall of 10 to 25 centimetres is expected this weekend. Hazards: 10 to 25 cm of snow Poor road conditions due to accumulating snow Poor visibility in local blowing snow and heavy snow Timing: Snow will begin Saturday morning and last into Sunday. The heaviest snow is expected Saturday afternoon through Sunday morning. Discussion: A snowstorm appears increasingly likely for eastern Manitoulin Island to North Bay. This corridor is where confidence is highest in the largest snowfall amounts. Strong winds in addition to fresh snow may create local blowing and drifting snow in exposed areas. A Snowfall Warning is being considered as this event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-12T08:45:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-11T16:46:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1371244707.2020
Area: Greater Sudbury and vicinity, Temiskaming Shores - Temagami, West Nipissing - French River, North Bay - Powassan - Mattawa, Espanola - Killarney, Manitoulin Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of freezing rain and rain is expected this weekend. Freezing rain will be favoured over higher terrain, while rain will be favoured elsewhere. Hazards: 20 to 30 mm of rain 5 to 15 mm of ice accretion over higher terrain Isolated power outages and slippery roads and surfaces in areas of freezing rain Timing: Rain and freezing rain will begin early Saturday morning and taper to drizzle by late Saturday evening. Discussion: Patchy snow flurries or some freezing drizzle tonight will change to steadier rain and freezing rain early Saturday morning. Elevation will be a key feature in this system: areas of higher terrain should see prolonged freezing rain and possibly ice storm conditions, whereas areas of lower terrain should experience mainly rain. A Rainfall Warning and a Freezing Rain Warning is being considered as this event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-12T08:50:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-11T16:51:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2137848716.2020
Area: Barrie - Collingwood - Hillsdale, Owen Sound - Blue Mountains - Northern Grey County, Hanover - Dundalk - Southern Grey County, Shelburne - Mansfield - Northern Dufferin County, Orangeville - Grand Valley - Southern Dufferin County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, ice pellets, and a prolonged period of freezing rain is possible this weekend. Hazards: Freezing rain, possibly lasting several hours. 3-8 mm of ice accretion. Local power outages and slippery surfaces. Timing: Precipitation will begin Saturday morning and last into Sunday. Discussion: An approaching system will bring a transition zone of precipitation with it from roughly the Dundalk Highlands east to Ottawa and eastern Ontario. Along this zone, several hours of freezing rain may be possible, favouring ice build up on untreated surfaces and power lines. Precipitation will likely include a mix of rain, snow, ice pellets, and freezing rain. Snowfall accumulations are generally anticipated to be limited to 5 cm or less. Freezing Rain Warnings will be considered as this event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-12T01:45:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-11T09:46:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2721612390.2020
Area: Gatineau, Merrickville-Wolford - Kemptville, Maxville - Alexandria, Cornwall - Lancaster, Winchester - Newington, Midland - Coldwater - Orr Lake, Orillia - Lagoon City - Washago, Barrie - Collingwood - Hillsdale, Port Carling - Port Severn, Bracebridge - Gravenhurst, Kaladar - Bannockburn - Bon Echo Park, Fenelon Falls - Balsam Lake Park - Northern Kawartha Lakes, Apsley - Woodview - Northern Peterborough County, Prescott and Russell, Smiths Falls - Perth - Eastern Lanark County, Plevna - Sharbot Lake - Western Lanark County, Ottawa North - Kanata - Orléans, Ottawa South - Richmond - Metcalfe, Shelburne - Mansfield - Northern Dufferin County, Orangeville - Grand Valley - Southern Dufferin County

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A sloppy morning commute is expected today. Total snowfall: up to 15 cm in the east, with lesser amounts in the west. Locations: Avalon Peninsula. Time span: early this morning until early this evening. Maximum wind gusts: northerly 60 to 70 km/h. Remarks: A low pressure system passing southeast of the island will continue to bring snow to the Avalon today. The snow is expected to mix with rain along parts of the coast. Eastern regions will generally get 5 to 10 cm, with higher local amounts over higher terrain. Temperatures are forecast to remain slightly above the freezing mark throughout the event. As a result, driving conditions are expected to be hazardous, especially during the morning commute, as the settling snow will become slushy on the roads and walkways. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-12-12T00:54:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-11T08:55:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1692563837.2020
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 5 to 15 cm of snow and ice pellets, plus a risk of freezing rain, is expected this weekend. Hazards: 5 to 15 cm of snow and ice pellets; up to 20 cm may be possible for places like Parry Sound and Huntsville. Poor road conditions due to accumulating snow and possible freezing rain. Timing: Snow will begin Friday overnight and last into Sunday. Discussion: This precipitation is a result of an approaching Texas low that will spread precipitation across a large portion of southern Ontario and parts of northeastern Ontario beginning Friday overnight. Areas east of Georgian Bay will see a wintry mix of snow, ice pellets, and a risk of freezing rain. At this point, a general range of 5 to 15 cm of snow and ice pellets seems reasonable with a risk of freezing rain. Up to 20 cm of snow is possible in places like Huntsville and Parry Sound. Snowfall warnings will be considered as the event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-12T01:45:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-11T09:46:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1916439837.2020
Area: Huntsville - Baysville, Town of Parry Sound - Rosseau - Killbear Park, Oxtongue Lake - Fort Irwin - Northern Haliburton County, Haliburton - Minden - Southern Haliburton County, Bancroft - Hastings Highlands - Denbigh, Petawawa - Pembroke - Cobden, Barry's Bay - Killaloe, Renfrew - Arnprior - Calabogie

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: 20 to 30 mm or rain plus a risk of freezing rain, is expected this weekend. Hazards: 20 to 30 mm of rain and potential for localized flooding. Poor road conditions due to possible freezing rain in areas of higher terrain. Timing: Rain or freezing rain will begin Friday overnight and last into Sunday. Precipitation may be mixed with snow Friday overnight and early Saturday morning. Discussion: This rain or freezing rain is a result of an approaching Texas low that will spread precipitation across a large portion of southern Ontario and parts of northeastern Ontario beginning Friday overnight. Rainfall warnings or freezing rain warnings will be considered as the event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Long-lasting blizzard conditions with potentially damaging winds and persistent visibility near zero in blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions will develop early this evening near the Richardson Mountains. Easterly winds will increase to 70 km/h gusting to 90 tonight and to 90 km/h gusting to 120 on Saturday and will combine with loose snow to reduce visibility to 400 metres or less. This blizzard is expected to last through the weekend. Winds will ease slightly Sunday night but visibility may still be poor in blowing snow. Blizzard conditions will abate early next week. ### Travel is expected to be very difficult or impossible due to near-zero visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-12T09:57:26-00:00

Area: Dempster

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected beginning late Saturday. Total snowfall: 15 to 20 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 40 to 60 km/h. Locations: central and northern New Brunswick. Time span: Saturday evening through Sunday night. Remarks: Heavy snow is expected to spread across parts of New Brunswick on Saturday evening, with strong winds and local blowing snow possible. The snow may change briefly to freezing rain or ice pellets over south-central parts of the province on Saturday night. Coastal regions along the Fundy shore should remain warm enough for rain with this system. There is some uncertainty with the track of this system at this time. The rain-snow line may shift slightly and warnings may be required as this system draws nearer. Conditions will improve across the Maritimes on Monday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-12T06:56:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-11T14:57:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2824288860.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Mixed bag of precipitation for the weekend. A low pressure system will bring a mixed bag of precipitation over Southern and Central Quebec on Saturday and Sunday. Precipitation is expected to begin as snow before changing over to freezing rain. Freezing rain could last for several hours before temperatures rise above the freezing mark. Areas to the south, near the U.S. border, could see rain only. Poor driving conditions are expected. Consider changing any non-essential travel plans. The track of the low remains relatively uncertain. Warnings will be issued when the scenario becomes clearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-12T08:21:35-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Sloppy conditions are expected Saturday on the Bruce Peninsula with 20 to 30 mm of rain or 10 to 20 cm of snow is expected this weekend. Hazards: 20 to 30 mm of rain 10 to 20 cm of snow across northern portions of the Bruce Peninsula Poor road conditions due to accumulating snow Timing: Steady precipitation will begin Friday overnight and last into Saturday evening. Discussion: An approaching system will spread precipitation ahead of it on Saturday. The fine line between heavy rain and heavy snow may find itself dividing the Bruce Peninsula this weekend, Tobermory and places in the north end of the peninsula should mainly experience snowfall, though a switch to rain in the day Saturday is possible before going back to snow after. Further south, including Wiarton, should experience mainly rainfall. A Rainfall Warning and a Snowfall Warning is being considered as this event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-12T10:29:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-11T18:30:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1094810686.2020
Area: Bruce Peninsula - Sauble Beach - Tobermory
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rainfall amounts of 20 to 30 mm is expected Saturday. Hazards: 20 to 30 mm of rain Timing: Rain will begin Friday overnight and taper off Saturday evening. Discussion: An approaching system will spread rain across the region Friday overnight. Due to recent precipitation and some snow cover, the ground's ability to absorb this rainfall has been greatly reduced. A Rainfall Warning will be considered as this event draws nearer. Note, Environment Canada's rainfall warning criteria is 25 mm of rain in 24 hours in the winter. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-12T10:39:00-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-11T18:40:00-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1760678567.2020

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A low pressure system tracking across Baffin Island is bringing very strong winds gusting at times to 70 km/h to Naujaat and Coral Harbour. This is resulting in significantly reduced visibilities in heavy blowing snow. In Naujaat, blizzard conditions are expected to improve early this morning. Meanwhile, at Coral Harbour, blizzard conditions will gradually improve towards midday. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-11T19:59:15-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-11T09:17:15-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3928713554.2020

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Dense fog persists late this morning in parts of southern Saskatchewan and southwest Manitoba. The area of fog extends roughly from east of the city of Regina into southwestern Manitoba including Brandon. Fog is also present south of Regina to the international border. The fog is expected to gradually lift as the afternoon progresses. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-12T00:02:17-00:00

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Dense fog patches are being reported across portions of extreme southern Saskatchewan. The fog will persist throughout the night with visibilities gradually improving late Friday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-11T20:02:56-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow storm this weekend. A low pressure system will bring significant snowfall amounts on Saturday and Sunday. Total amounts will range from 15 to 30 centimetres depending on the area. Snow will begin over Western Quebec Saturday before reaching Eastern Quebec the following night. Poor driving conditions are expected. Consider changing any non-essential travel plans. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-12T08:23:12-00:00
